channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Russia Shrinks Forces in Syria, a Factor in Israeli Strategy There
item.description: Moscow withdrew a key air defense system and some troops to bolster its war in Ukraine, officials said, potentially altering Israel’s calculations about striking Syria or arming Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Ronen Bergman
item.media:description: Russian military police in the northeastern Syrian city of Qamishli in 2020. Moscow is sending more military police to Syria to help replace troops withdrawn from the country.

item.title: Times Square May Get One of the Few Spectacles It Lacks: A Casino
item.description: The battle to win a New York City casino license has heated up in Manhattan, with real estate and gambling giants offering competing proposals for Times Square and Hudson Yards.
item.dc:creator: Dana Rubinstein, Nicole Hong and Michael Paulson
item.media:credit: Christopher Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: The new proposal for a Times Square casino already faces opposition from the Broadway League, a trade association representing theater owners and producers.

item.title: Could a Market Blowout Like the UK’s Happen in the US?
item.description: Federal Reserve and White House officials spent last week quizzing investors and economists about the risks of a British-style meltdown at home.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek, Jim Tankersley and Joe Rennison
item.media:credit: John Taggart for The New York Times
item.media:description: Investors and market economists are increasingly concerned that, given how much policy has shifted around the world, something could easily go wrong.

item.title: Consumer Giants Keep Raising Prices as Profits Come Under Pressure
item.description: Nestlé and Procter & Gamble reported resilient earnings as they brought in more money from selling fewer goods.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Simonetti
item.media:description: Procter & Gamble, the owner of Charmin toilet paper and other consumer brands, raised prices by 9 percent in its latest quarter.

item.title: Liz Truss Fires Home Secretary Suella Braverman After Email Breach
item.description: Britain’s prime minister dismissed Suella Braverman after an email breach. Ms. Truss was also grilled in Parliament over her repudiated budget.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Liz Truss of Britain said she would guarantee a pension increase that her finance chief had called into question.

item.title: Liz Truss or Lettuce: British Newspaper Tracks Who Will Wilt First
item.description: Inspired by a columnist’s turn of phrase, a British newspaper is tracking whether the embattled prime minister can outlast off-the-shelf produce.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor

item.title: Videos Show Confusion as Florida Police Arrest People on Voter Fraud Charges
item.description: A crackdown in August on voter fraud announced by Gov. Ron DeSantis seems to have ensnared former felons who were puzzled that they were accused of violating voting laws.
item.dc:creator: Michael Wines and Neil Vigdor

item.title: Goodbye Planes, Trains and Automobiles. Hello, Luxury Bus?
item.description: Start-up travel companies are hoping more Americans will embrace the concept of sleeper and luxury coaches. Just don’t call them buses.
item.dc:creator: Maria Cramer
item.category: Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Passengers on the Napaway coach get comfortable as the bus leaves Washington, D.C., on Oct. 14 for an overnight trip to Nashville.

item.title: Judge Says Trump Signed Statement With Data His Lawyers Told Him Was False
item.description: The determination came in a decision by a federal judge that John Eastman, a lawyer for the former president, had to turn more of his emails over to the House Jan. 6 committee.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater and Alan Feuer
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
item.media:description: The House committee investigating Jan. 6 views John Eastman as the intellectual architect of plans to subvert the 2020 election.

item.title: Zeldin Built His Profile Defending Trump. Will New Yorkers Mind?
item.description: Lee Zeldin, a Republican congressman from Long Island, voted to overturn 2020 election results and blamed Democrats for Jan. 6 violence. Now, he wants to lead New York State.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
item.media:description: Representative Lee Zeldin, at the 2022 Columbus Day Parade, was one of the earliest congressmen to encourage Donald J. Trump’s presidential bid.

item.title: What’s on the Minds of 12 Young Voters
item.description: For these Americans under 30, all living in swing states, political priorities ranged from the highly personal to the universal.
item.media:credit: From left, Nicole Craine for The New York Times, Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times, Hannah Beier for The New York Times

item.title: Biden Expands Effort to Lower Gas Prices and Secure Energy Independence
item.description: Depleting emergency oil reserves spurs criticism that the White House is trying to lower gas prices with midterm election politics in mind.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport and Ana Swanson
item.media:description: President Biden said that he has ordered the release of 15 million additional barrels of oil from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve to address gas shortage concerns.

item.title: Suzanne Scott’s Vision for Fox News Gets Tested in Court
item.description: Suzanne Scott remade Fox News Media into a lucrative consumer brand. But a defamation suit against the company is a test of her strategy and leadership.
item.dc:creator: Jeremy W. Peters and Rachel Abrams

item.title: How Did a Minister Come to Own Hundreds of Edward Hoppers?
item.description: An exhibition at the Whitney Museum of American Art exploring Hopper’s vision of New York has also rekindled questions about how a Baptist minister came to own so much of his art.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Flynn, Julia Jacobs and Robin Pogrebin
item.media:credit: Heirs of Josephine N. Hopper/Licensed by Artists Rights Society (ARS), New York
item.media:description: “City Roofs,” an oil by Edward Hopper from 1932, is among the works in the new Whitney show that were once owned by the Rev. Arthayer R. Sanborn. It depicts the view from the roof of the Greenwich Village building where Hopper lived.

item.title: Kanye West Is Running Out of Platforms
item.description: The act of grabbing public attention has been a centerpiece of Kanye West’s art for two decades. Will audiences still tune in if his only outlets are on the fringes?
item.dc:creator: Jon Caramanica
item.media:credit: Julian Berman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Over the last two weeks, Ye has unleashed a string of racial provocations and antisemitic statements at a fashion show, on social media and in interviews.

item.title: Has Polling Broken Politics?
item.description: As the midterms near, Margie Omero and Nate Silver consider what voter surveys are good for.
item.dc:creator: ‘The Argument’

item.title: When Robbing Your Own Bank Account Is the Only Option
item.description: The Lebanese want their money, and they’re done asking politely.
item.dc:creator: Lina Mounzer

item.title: The Mess in Los Angeles Points to Trouble for Democrats
item.description: The City of Angels is no stranger to zero-sum politics.
item.dc:creator: Thomas B. Edsall
item.media:credit: Genaro Molina/Los Angeles Times, via Getty Images

item.title: Natural Disasters Affect Children in Utero. What Can Parents Do?
item.description: Parents shouldn’t freak out. We should push for change.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Grose

item.title: America and China Don’t Need to Knock Each Other Out to Win
item.description: China and the United States should invest more resources in a vision of success not defined by undermining the other.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Chen Weiss
item.media:description: Chinese military conducted live-fire military exercises to intimidate Taiwan after a high-profile visit by Nancy Pelosi, the House speaker, to Taipei in August.

item.title: We Advised Biden on the Pandemic. Much Work Remains to Face the Next Crisis.
item.description: Even with the successes against Covid, there is much room for improvement.
item.dc:creator: Ezekiel J. Emanuel, David Michaels, Rick Bright and Michael T. Osterholm
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

item.title: Is Wall Street Really to Blame for the Affordable Housing Crisis?
item.description: Affordable housing has become harder and harder to find. Could corporate speculators be the culprit?
item.dc:creator: Spencer Bokat-Lindell
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times; images by Drew Angerer and John Moore, via Getty Images

item.title: Thank You, Xi Jinping
item.description: China’s paramount leader is restoring faith in the free world — inadvertently, of course.
item.dc:creator: Bret Stephens

item.title: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Russian forces have continued to shell several Ukrainian cities, including Bakhmut.

item.title: Threat to Democracy? Start With Corruption, Many Voters Say
item.description: In a Times/Siena survey, respondents’ concerns about democracy often diverged from typical expert analysis.
item.dc:creator: Nate Cohn
item.media:credit: Rebecca Noble for The New York Times
item.media:description: A rally called Save America last week in Mesa, Ariz. People have very different ideas of what that term means.

item.title: Encore: A Lifetime of Good Loving
item.description: After 56 years of marriage, a widow finds hope for the future by remembering the sweetness of life spent together.

item.title: 🍄 It’s Mushroom Week! 🍄
item.description: A big batch of mushroom ragout means many delicious meals ahead.
item.dc:creator: Tejal Rao
item.media:credit: Beatriz Da Costa for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Rebecca Jurkevich.

item.title: Tesla Reports Strong Profit in Third Quarter on Soaring Sales
item.description: The electric carmaker is growing fast but investors are worried that sales are starting to slow because of higher prices and interest rates.
item.dc:creator: Neal E. Boudette
item.media:credit: Roger Kisby for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tesla sales rose in the third quarter.

item.title: Preserving a Palestinian Identity in the Kitchen
item.description: With many Palestinians fearful that their cuisine is being lost, kitchen practices handed down by family matriarchs for generations are still being passed along.
item.dc:creator: Aina J. Khan
item.media:credit: Samar Hazboun for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mariam Sindawi in the kitchen of her home, in Haifa, Israel, with her granddaughter Abeer Abbasi. “Our relationship is really based around the kitchen,” Ms. Abbasi said.

item.title: Webb Telescope Captures New View of ‘Pillars of Creation’
item.description: The NASA space observatory’s infrared eye finds out what’s going on within the cloudy cosmic nursery.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye
item.media:description: “Pillars of Creation” captured in NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope’s near-infrared view. The pillars resemble arches and spires rising from a desert, but are filled with semitransparent gas and dust.

item.title: These Doctors Admit They Don’t Want Patients With Disabilities
item.description: When granted anonymity in focus groups, physicians let their guards down and shared opinions consistent with experiences of many people with disabilities.
item.dc:creator: Gina Kolata
item.media:credit: M. Scott Brauer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lisa Iezzoni, a professor of medicine at Harvard, wanted to understand why people with disabilities kept reporting receiving substandard care. “I thought I needed to start talking to doctors,” she said.

item.title: Quitting Smoking: Can E-Cigarettes Help?
item.description: Here’s what the evidence suggests.
item.dc:creator: Jen A. Miller
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: What Are Neti Pots and How Do They Work?
item.description: Nasal rinsing has been used for thousands of years to relieve sinus inflammation, congestion, allergy symptoms and more. Here’s what the evidence says.
item.dc:creator: Alice Callahan

item.title: How Many Close Friends Do You Need in Adulthood?
item.description: Social circles were shrinking even before the pandemic. Here’s what the science says about the number of close friendships we should have.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Pearson

item.title: Grind Your Teeth? Your Night Guard May Not Be the Right Fix
item.description: Some experts say tooth-grinding is a behavior rather than a disorder, and the dentist’s chair isn’t the best place to address it.
item.dc:creator: Kate Murphy

item.title: Lars Eidinger Might Be the Greatest German Actor You’ve Never Heard Of
item.description: He might be the greatest Shakespearean actor you’ve never heard of. At last, New Yorkers will get to see his no-holds-barred portrayal of Hamlet in Thomas Ostermeier’s production at BAM.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Vincentelli
item.media:credit: Justin J Wee for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I believe in the genius of creation out of the moment,” the German actor Lars Eidinger said. “You invent something out of an impulse because you are open-minded, but you are not aware how meaningful it is.”

item.title: How to Solve Hard Crosswords
item.description: Friday, Saturday and Sunday bring some of the hardest puzzles of the week.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
